revision.comment: /* Create a page without a form */
revision.text:
You can create a new page for any entity or source that is within the scope of this project if it doesn't already have a page in this wiki. Pages are usually created by forms. The lists below tell you which form to use for which type of thing. Most forms will ask you to enter the name of the page that you want to create. Please check [[Help:Page name conventions]] before deciding what to call it, but don't worry too much about getting it wrong as we can easily change it later. Some types of pages have numbers automatically assigned, so you don't need to specify a name for the page.
You can also create pages by clicking on red links. In this case you may be forwarded to the correct form, or you may be taken to another page that asks you to choose a form. You may need to look at the present page to help you choose the right form (you can have this page open in another tab or window if it helps).
== Historical entities ==
These entities represent individual people, places, organizations or events that existed in the 17th century.
Location and Event pages for each unit or agent should always be created using the red links on that unit or agent's page. This will always forward you to the correct form.
=== People and animals ===
* [[Form:Agent|Agent]] for historical people and animals of any other species who were alive between the 1630s and 1660s. Can also be used for people who died before the 1630s if it's possible and useful to record the location of their remains . * [[Form:Author|Author]] for people who were not alive in this period and are only included as authors or editors of sources.
=== Places and organizations ===
* [[Form:Address|Address]] is used for physical locations such as towns, villages, buildings and streets. * [[Form:Unit|Unit]] is for organizations that occupied a specific location and could move (even if they didn't move much in practice). This includes: ** military units ** ships ** committees ** guilds and companies ** households * [[Form:Area|Area]] is for administrative organizations that covered a geographical area. The boundaries of the area may have changed, but the location of the organization can't move drastically. This includes: ** wartime associations ** parishes and their sub-units, such as townships and chapelries ** ecclesiastical units such as rural deaneries, archdeaconries, dioceses, and peculiar jurisdictions ** civil units such as hundreds, boroughs, and counties. Counties will usually be represented by several areas: *** county at large (the largest extent of a shire, including any corporate counties) *** commission of the peace *** shrievalty *** lieutenancy ** parliamentary constituencies, including boroughs, shires and corporate counties. A constituency will always be represented as a separate entity even if it has the same name and area as a county or borough.
=== Events ===
* [[Form:Event|Event]] is now used for all battles, sieges and other combat events, and for formal meetings of organizations. In future it could be used for other types of events.
== Sources ==
* [[Form:GLAM|GLAM]] represents a gallery, library, archive, or museum that holds manuscripts, early printed books, images, or material objects (although only manuscripts have been implemented here) * [[Form:Collection|Collection]] is currently used to represent a collection of manuscripts held by a GLAM. It can cover any level from an individual volume containing multiple documents to a series of volumes. Collections can be parents of other collections. Note that some manuscript volumes are counted as [[Form:Manuscript text|Manuscript text]] if the whole volume is part of the same text such as a diary. At [[The National Archives of the UK (TNA)|TNA]] a collection can cover a department code, series, sub-series, piece, or part within a piece. At the [[British Library]] it can cover an individual volume or a series of volumes. * [[Form:Author|Author]] is for authors or editors of sources who were not alive between the 1630s and 1660s. * [[Form:Serial publication|Serial publication]] can represent any serial publication published at any time. This includes: ** 17th-century newsbooks ** modern academic journals ** magazines ** record society series ** a series of monographs or edited collections
=== Works ===
* [[Form:Work|Work]] is used for works that have more than one version (including printed editions and manuscripts copies), or for works that have Wikidata IDs. If neither of these things apply, work level is not represented.
(All works are now named. We are not using unnamed works any more so the relevant form, template and category have been deleted.)
A version can have more than one parent work if it is a compilation of more than one work.
=== Manuscripts ===
* [[Form:Manuscript text|Manuscript text]] is used for an individual text that survives in manuscript * {{#formlink:form=Lost manuscript text|link text=Lost manuscript text|link type=}} is for a text that is known to have existed in manuscript but has since been lost. This can be because it is known to have been destroyed, or because its current location is unknown. It can also be used for manuscripts that are known to survive in a private collection if the owner does not want to be identified, or if the collection does not have formal catalogue references. This form automatically generates a number for the page name, so you don't need to choose a name before you create the page. * [[Form:Manuscript text section|Manuscript text section]] is a division of a text. This can be: ** physical, such as a page or folio ** logical, such as a chapter ** arbitrary, such as a passage of a narrative that covers a certain event, even if the author didn't distinguish it in any way (this can be useful for linking accounts of battles, for example) * [[Form:Blank|Blank]] represents one or more blank pages in a manuscript. It has very few properties but is useful for indicating that there is no text. Its parent can be a collection, a manuscript text or a section.
Whether lost or extant, a manuscript text usually represents one individual document such as:
* a letter * a petition * a pay warrant * an account book * a diary
A text can be a parent of another text, for example:
* a letter book is a text, and each letter copied into it is also a text * an account book is a text; if it contains copies of warrants and/or receipts, each of these is also a text * a volume of a probate register is a text, and each will copied into it is also a text
=== Published editions: books ===
* [[Form:Early edition|Early edition]] represents an edition of a work published as a book before 1800. This usually corresponds to one ESTC number even if there are different ESTC numbers for minor variations of what is substantially the same edition. This now only has one level of edition and no formats. * [[Form:Modern edition|Modern edition]] represents an edition of a work published as a book after 1800. Formats are now subtemplates embedded in edition pages.
A book can mean:
* a monograph * an edited collection * a record society volume * an issue of a 17th-century newsbook or other serial * a broadside (not technically a book but classed as a book for convenience)
A book is classed as an edition if:
* it's the first published edition * it's explicitly numbered as a subsequent edition (eg 2nd edition) * it has substantial changes to the text compared to an earlier edition, or if it adds extra text such as a new foreword, preface, introduction, appendix or editorial notes * it adds a new author or editor * it's a translation into a different language * it appears in a different format from another edition, for example if the same work is published as an article and a book * it's a compilation of more than one work that have also been published separately or in different combinations * it's a different issue of a periodical * it has a different ESTC number * it's a modern facsimile reprint of an early edition
You can combine work level into the same page as an edition if there is only one edition published as a book, and no versions in article or manuscript form.
=== Published editions: articles and chapters ===
[[Form:Article|Article]] is used for an edition of a work that was published as:
* a journal or magazine article * a chapter in an edited collection
Every version of an article or chapter should have its own page, even if the text has not changed. This includes legally self-archived versions as well as publishers' versions of record, unless the self-archived version is exactly the same, including the same typography and pagination, as the version of record. Each version of an article is counted as an edition, and there are no formats.
You can combine work level into the same page as an article if it only has one version and that version was published as an article.
=== Theses and dissertations ===
* [[Form:Thesis|Thesis]] is used for any thesis or dissertation. They are represented only at one level, not as works and editions. A thesis is not treated as part of the same work as 'the book of the thesis'.
The university associated with a thesis is not represented here as semantic data but can be found by following external links.
== Subject headings ==
[[Form:Subject heading|Subject heading]] is used to create and edit pages that represent general themes rather than specific individual entities. These can be used as values of [[Property:Has main subject]].
== Entity type definitions ==
[[Form:Type definition|Type definition]] is used to create and edit pages that define types of entity, such as the various types of military unit or manuscript text. These are all used as values of [[Property:Is instance of]].
== Role definitions ==
[[Form:Role definition|Role definition]] is used to create and edit pages that define roles used for command relationships, event participation, and personnel relationships.
== Categories ==
[[Special:CreateCategory|Create category]] is the easiest way to create a new category as it has a dropdown list to help you select a parent category.
You can also create a category without a form by clicking a red link.
== Create a page without a form ==
Some kinds of pages don't have a form. These include:
* freeform pages about more general historical topics that don't represent an individual entity or source * pages that define a custom query, such as [[Events:Map of combat events]] * disambiguation pages * redirects * help pages * non-semantic templates
To create a page without a form, type the page name in the box below and click 'Create page':
<inputbox> type=create break=no </inputbox>
[[Category:Help pages]]

This is a property of type [[Has type::Date]]. It represents the actual start date of an entity if the actual start date is definitely known. It is used for these entities:
* Units in [[Template:Unit]] * Events in [[Template:Event]] * Command relationships in [[Template:Command relationship subobject]] * Personnel relationships in [[Template:Personnel subobject]] * Locations in [[Template:Location subobject]]
Values for this property are usually also automatically assigned to [[Property:Has earliest known date]].
See [[Help:Dates]] for more information on how to enter dates.

This is a property of type [[Has type::Date]]. It represents the actual end date of an entity if the actual end date is definitely known. It is used for these entities:
* Units in [[Template:Unit]] * Events in [[Template:Event]] * Command relationships in [[Template:Command relationship subobject]] * Personnel relationships in [[Template:Personnel subobject]] * Locations in [[Template:Location subobject]]
Values for this property are usually also automatically assigned to [[Property:Has latest known date]].
See [[Help:Dates]] for more information on how to enter dates.

revision.comment: allowed values

revision.text:
(Links created by this property are currently broken because of the cyber attack on the British Library in October 2023. A limited version of the main catalogue is now available but it has a different domain name and the old permalinks do not work.)
This is a property of type [[Has type::External identifier]]. It represents a UIN code from the [http://explore.bl.uk/ British Library Main Catalogue]. It will be automatically formatted as a URI in this form (where $1 is the value you entered):
[[External formatter uri::http://explore.bl.uk/BLVU1:LSCOP-ALL:$1]]
It is usually used for [[modern edition]]s of books that do not have an ISBN.
Similar to Wikidata property [[Wikidata:Property:P5199|P5199]] but formatted slightly differently.
This is a property of type [[Has type::Page]]. It shows that a printed or manuscript text is an edition of a [[work]].

revision.comment: updated definition
revision.text:
This is a property of type [[Has type::Page]]. It represents a person who put an original signature, initials, mark, or seal on a manuscript text. It should only be used if the manuscript contains original signs. If the manuscript is a copy that does not contain the original signs, the value for this property should be [[None]]. If a later copy has a signed certificate of authenticity written on the same paper, the certificate should be represented as a separate child text. If the original of the copy does not survive, you can create a [[Form:Lost manuscript text|Lost manuscript text]] and enter the signatories there.
We do not distinguish between signatures, initials, and marks because the boundaries between these things can be hard to define, and because Signs of Literacy is already collecting data about literacy.

revision.comment: /* Disambiguation pages */ changed conventions
revision.text:
A wiki page name is an identifier for a page within a wiki. This page may be about a named entity (person, place, organization) but strictly speaking, the page name is an identifier for a resource about that entity, not for the entity itself. Where possible, entities are more rigorously identified by linking to external identifiers.
Page names must be '''unique''' and need to get a balance between '''short''' and '''informative'''. This means that the page name should contain enough information for human readers to be able to find what they're looking for, but no more information than is necessary for that.
A page name '''is not''' a full name history of the entity, and does not always have to show the most correct name for that entity.
== Special characters ==
These characters should not be used in page names:
{| class="swordinfotable" !Character !Reasons |- |<nowiki># < > [ ] { } |</nowiki> |These will interfere with wiki markup or HTML markup. |- |& |The ampersand is used for query strings in web addresses. Mediawiki can work around this but we prefer to use 'and' in page names to avoid confusion. |- |: |The colon is used by Mediawiki to signify namespaces. It will work as part of a page name if the prefix is not a namespace, but it can be confusing so we prefer to avoid it even though it is allowed in some other wikis. |- |/ |The forward slash can be used in most page names, and is often needed in archival references, but it should be avoided in page names for Agents or Units because it can cause problems when creating subpages in the Events and Locations namespaces. We now use \ to separate multiple commanders' surnames in the page names for military units. |- |? + = |These have special meaning in web addresses. In wiki page names it might work in practice, but it's better to avoid it . |}
Apart from these, any Latin unicode characters can and should be used to spell names correctly. It's better to transliterate characters from other alphabets into the Latin alphabet. All text added to this site should use UTF-8 character encoding.
== People ==
People can be [[Form:Agent|Agents]] (if they were alive during the British Civil Wars) or [[Form:Author|Authors]] (if they weren't alive at this time and are only included as authors or editors of published texts. Similar naming conventions apply to both.
Surnames should usually come first, followed by a comma, then by forenames and/or initials. The main exception to this rule is for royalty who are commonly known by forenames and either don't have surnames or who are not commonly known by their surname. In this case, the forename comes first, followed by a comma, followed by a royal title. Years of birth and death may be added for disambiguation to compensate for lack of a surname. For example:
* [[Rupert, Prince]] * [[Charles I]]
For people whose surname comes first, the qualifiers 'junior' or 'senior' may be used if necessary for disambiguation. These come after the forenames, separated by a space, not a comma:
* Balfour, William senior * Balfour, William junior
Further titles (except peerages: see below) may be used after another comma if needed for disambiguation:
* Balfour, William senior, Sir * Balfour, William junior, Major
A military rank may be used directly after surname if the forename is not known:
* Smith, Captain
Any additional disambiguation information usually goes in round brackets after these names.
Years of birth and/or death should only be used if they are absolutely necessary for disambiguation and are certainly known. Often they can be omitted. If they are included, they should be the first thing inside the brackets, before anything else.
Only the most distinctive occupation or other role should be used: the purpose is disambiguation, not to provide a comprehensive description of a person's life.
For modern historians, it's usually only necessary to put 'historian' in brackets. Peerages, knighthoods and other titles can be included. For example:
* [[Russell, Conrad (5th Earl Russell, historian)]] * [[Roy, Ian (historian)]] * [[Hopper, Andrew (historian)]]
It's best if the actual page name uses one or more full forenames unless the historian is much better known by their initials:
* [[Gardiner, S R (historian)]]
But alternative forms with initials can also be redirects. In either case, there are no full points after an initial.
Page names should usually use a person's most well-known name. The original spelling from a historical person's signature is preferred if known, but this won't be enforced rigidly.
The words 'royalist' and 'parliamentarian' should only be used as qualifiers if a person held an actual position in the organization of one side and never for the other, and if these qualifiers are particularly useful for disambiguation or identification of a person.
=== Peers ===
Use only surname, forename, and highest/last title held. Year of death is no longer included:
* [[Devereux, Robert (3rd Earl of Essex)]] * [[Cavendish, William (1st Duke of Newcastle)]]
There should be a redirect for every peer with the title first and the name in brackets:
* [[Essex, Earl of, 3rd (Robert Devereux)]]
There can also be redirects for previous or subsidiary titles but only the highest/last main title should be used in an actual page name.
=== Married surnames ===
Some people take a new surname on marriage. This has traditionally applied to women in Britain but men and nonbinary people might also take a new surname on marriage.
We have no strict rule about whether to use maiden or married surnames where all are known. Use whichever seems most widely used or easy to understand, even if inconsistent. In some cases, a historical widow's maiden name might not be known.
Examples:
* [[Cavendish, Margaret (Duchess of Newcastle)]] uses her married name but was born Margaret Lucas. * [[Howard, Frances (Countess of Essex and Somerset)]] uses her maiden name. Her married names were Devereux and then Carr. * [[Willingham, Anne (nee Eaton)]] uses her married name first but has her maiden name in brackets. * [[Betts, Elizabeath (saddler)]] a widow whose maiden name is currently unknown. * [[Mulligan, Lotte (nee Glow, historian)]] uses her married name first but has her maiden name in brackets.
There can be redirects for other surnames.
If a living historian has a married surname but always uses her maiden name professionally, her married surname should be treated as private and not mentioned anywhere on this site.
=== Transgendered people ===
Living transgendered people's deadnames '''must not''' be mentioned anywhere on this site. They may be mentioned in sources linked to by external identifiers but we can't help that.
== Military units ==
Armies are capitalized and should have as short names as possible. Allegiance can be added after a comma if needed for disambiguation, but can often be left out. Armies can be known by a commander's name, a place name, or both. Sometimes years of existence are needed for disambiguation. Examples:
* [[Essex's Army]] * [[Oxford Army]] * [[Eastern Association Army]] * [[New Model Army]] * [[Army of Covenant (2nd Bishops War)]] * [[Army of Covenant (1643-47)]] * [[Newcastle's Army]]
Units such as regiments, troops and companies were mostly known by the commanding officer's name and did not have official names of their own. In these cases, the page name should have two parts separated by '-'. The first part should be the names of one or more commanding officers. The second part should be the type of unit and any other information needed for disambiguation, such as the army it was in, the side it was on, or the years when it existed.
The first part should put a surname first. If there was only one commanding officer, the forename can be used in the same way as pages for people, but sometimes it can be omitted if the unit or colonel is very well known or there were no similarly named units. If there were multiple commanding officers, multiple surnames can be used, separated by '\' (we no longer use '/' as it can cause confusion when creating subpages in the Events and Locations namespaces). Commanders' names don't have to be in chronological order. It's better to start with the name that seems to be best known or that was used for longest, but this is flexible as cases will vary. Not every commander has to be included in the page name, especially if they only served for a short time. Extra disambiguation information such as ranks, titles or senior/junior can be added if needed.
The second part should start with a unit type, such as 'horse troop' or 'foot regiment'. This is usually in lower case because it's a description, not a proper noun. If the army, allegiance or other parent unit are needed for disambiguation, the can go next after a comma. Army names should be capitalized but regiment names shouldn't. New Model Army units will probably always have 'New Model Army' in the page name, and will be treated as separate units from their predecessors. Any other disambiguation information, such as years active, can go in brackets.
Examples:
* [[Cromwell\Vermuyden\Disbrowe - horse regiment, New Model Army]] * Balfour, William senior, Sir - horse troop, Essex's Army * Balfour, William junior, Major - horse troop, Essex's Army * Cromwell\St John\Cooper - horse troop * Cromwell, Oliver junior - horse troop, Eastern Association * Long, Walter - horse troop (1642) * Long, Walter - horse troop (1643)
There should be a redirect for every commanding officer. These should start with surname then forename like person pages. Names of other commanding officers should be added in brackets only if they are absolutely necessary for disambiguation. For example, these redirect to [[Cromwell\Vermuyden\Disbrowe - horse regiment, New Model Army]]:
* [[Vermuyden, Bartholomew - horse regiment, New Model Army]] * [[Disbrowe, John - horse regiment, New Model Army]]
== Households ==
A unit page that represents a household should usually start with the page name of the head of household followed by '- household'. For example:
* [[Willingham, George (-1651, London merchant) - household]]
== Places ==
Counties of England, Scotland and Wales should usually have the English name used by the [http://www.county-borders.co.uk/ Historic Counties Standard] followed by a comma then the country name:
* [[Essex, England]] * [[Denbighshire, Wales]] * [[East Lothian, Scotland]]
There should be a redirect for:
* alternative English names shown in the Historic Counties Standard * Welsh language names of Welsh counties. Most are shown in the Historic Counties Standard. Some alternatives come from Wikipedia. Country suffix should be ', Cymru'. * Gaelic names of Scottish counties. These are mostly taken from [https://www.ainmean-aite.scot/ Ainmean-Àite na h-Alba]. A few that are not explicitly given there are taken from Wikipedia or other sources. Country suffix should be ', Alba'. * we don't yet have a source for Scots names of Scottish counties where these differ from English names.
Settlements should have name, county at large and country:
* [[Colchester, Essex, England]] * [[Coggeshall, Essex, England]]
Except that county should be omitted if the county name is taken from and very close to a city name. For example, 'Gloucester, England' not 'Gloucester, Gloucestershire, England'.
Places in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire should also be qualified by the name of the riding, even if the page name would be unique without it:
* [[Grimsby, Lindsey, Lincolnshire, England]] * [[Doncaster, West Riding, Yorkshire, England]]
May need further disambiguation if two places have same name in same county.
Spellings of settlement names should usually be the English names used by Ordnance Survey data, unless there is a good reason to use an older name. Hyphens between words are replaced by spaces in page names, for example, 'Stratford upon Avon', not 'Stratford-upon-Avon'. There should be redirects for versions with hyphens. This rule does not apply to English names of settlements in Scotland where the hyphen is used to add a suffix such as -head or -side.
There should be redirects for Welsh and Gaelic names if shown in Ordnance Survey data, or if they can easily be imported from other sources. [This rule may need changing after more detailed examination of OS data.] Welsh Language Commissioner has a [http://www.comisiynyddygymraeg.cymru/English/Commissioner/PlaceNames/Pages/Download.aspx CSV file of Welsh places names], linked to OS IDs, available under OGL.
Durham is a special case. Use:
* for the settlement page: [[Durham (settlement), England]] * for the county page: [[Durham (county), England]] * suffix for pages for other places in the county: County Durham, England
Rural parishes should usually be settlement name followed by parish:
* [[Great Missenden parish, Buckinghamshire, England]] * Hawerby cum Beesby parish, Lincolnshire, England
Similarly, subunits should be settlement name + chapelry/township/hamlet/whatever.
But urban parishes should be disambiguated by saint's name:
* St Botolph Aldgate parish, London, England
Parish churches should have pages with same names as parishes but with 'church' instead of 'parish':
* Earls Colne church, Essex, England * St Botolph Aldgate church, London, England
St is usually preferred to Saint as this style is used by Ordnance Survey data for most place names.
But where a parish name combines more than one settlement, it's better to name the church only after the settlement where it actually is (if this is known), not after the whole parish. For example, 'Hawerby church, Lincolnshire, England' not 'Hawerby cum Beesby church, Lincolnshire, England'.
Other buildings should usually have the name of the building and the name of the settlement they are in or near, unless the settlement name already appears in the building name (this often happens with castles). Urban buildings should also have the street if it's known and useful. Oxford and Cambridge colleges should have Address pages to represent the buildings, and these should be qualified with ' buildings' at the end of the page name to disambiguate them from Unit pages that represent the college as an organization.
Boroughs and corporate counties should be separate entities from settlements in them:
* Colchester borough, England * [[Lincoln city, England]] * [[London city, England]]
Separate entities for county and borough jurisdictions:
* Essex commission of the peace, England * [[Essex shrievalty, England]] * Essex lieutenancy, England * [[Essex constituency, England]] * [[Colchester constituency, Essex, England]] * Lincolnshire commission of the peace, England * Lincoln commission of the peace, England
Ecclesiastical units:
* Lincoln diocese, England * Lincoln archdeaconry, England * Dorchester deanery, England * Edinburgh synod, Scotland * Peebles presbytery, Scotland
Names for these are initially taken from Ecton's ''Liber Valorum'' for England and Wales, or ''Fasti Ecclesiae Scoticanae'' for Scotland but can be improved from other sources.
== Events ==
=== Combat events ===
Start with place name, then date and event type in round brackets. For events that took place in one day, use the full date including calendar. Sieges can often just use the year but if the same place was besieged more than once in a year, the date can be expanded as much as is needed for disambiguation. Event type can include battle, skirmish, siege, assault, sally, storming or anything else that seems appropriate. It doesn't have to match the semantic data. The distinction between battles and skirmishes isn't rigid.
* [[Edgehill (1642-10-23 JL, battle)]] * [[Gloucester (1643, siege)]]
=== Meetings ===
Start with the name of the organization that held the meeting, then full date including calendar in round brackets. For example:
* [[Council of War, Essex's Army (1644-06-19 JL)]] * [[House of Commons, Short Parliament (1640-04-13 JL)]] * [[House of Lords, Short Parliament (1640-05-05 JL)]]
== Manuscripts and collections ==
Should start with GLAM name followed by comma. [[The National Archives of the UK (TNA)]] is abbreviated to TNA, but most other GLAMs are not abbreviated:
* TNA, * British Library, * Bodleian Library,
Then full catalogue reference eg for pieces/volumes:
* British Library, Add MS 18980 * TNA, SP 28/131/3 * Bodleian Library, MS Tanner 62
For lower collection levels, individual texts, and sections, include folio numbers where necessary:
* British Library, Add MS 18980, f. 1 * TNA, SP 28/131/3, f. 1 * Bodleian Library, MS Tanner 62, f. 1
If individual documents in a box don't have official item numbers, the page name can have ordinal numbers in brackets. For example:
* TNA, SP 28/151 (2nd item)
In this case, the orderable reference would be 'SP 28/151' and citable reference would be 'SP 28/151 unfol.'.
We may use the same approach where documents don't have folio numbers.
These will all need default sort string setting (this can be done in editing form) otherwise they won't sort in a sensible order. In the sort string, components should be separated by spaces, not commas or slashes. Numbers should be zero filled to the highest number of digits expected in that context.
For example, pieces in [[TNA, SP 28]] can have up to 3 digits, so the sort string for [[TNA, SP 28/4]] is 'TNA SP 28 004'.
== Printed sources ==
If more than one level (work, edition, format) is combined into the same page, that page should usually use the naming conventions for edition level. If another edition is added later, the edition page should stay as it is and a new page should be created for work level.
=== Works ===
Author surnames and short title will usually do. Use - to separate authors from title because commas can be used in title and italics can't be used in a page name.
* Wanklyn and Jones - Military History * Cruso - Military Instructions * Robinson - Horses, People and Parliament
=== Modern book editions ===
Usually as work title but qualified by edition (which can be either an ordinal number or the name of an editor) and year of first publication in brackets:
* Wanklyn and Jones - Military History (1st edition, 2005)
=== Early book editions ===
As modern editions, but will usually have an [[Property:Has_ESTC_number|ESTC number]]. This should go at the end of the bracketed part of the page name. For example:
* Cruso - Military Instructions (1st edition, 1632, ESTC S121933)
=== Journals/serials ===
Journals use full current names but omit 'The' from start. Redirects can be used to help find journals under old titles, but these should not be used as property values.
Examples:
* [[British Journal for Military History]] * [[War in History]]
Series of monographs should be in the form 'Series title (Publisher)'. More than one publisher can be included in the brackets if the series has changed publisher. There should also be redirects in the form 'Publisher - Series title' for every publisher of a series, even if there is only one.
Example:
* [[Century of the Soldier (Helion)]]
=== Articles ===
Journal article version of record:
* Author surname ' - ' abbreviated title (journal, publication year)
Journal names are usually full but can be abbreviated if the abbreviation is well known or the full title is very long.
Journal article self-archived version:
* Author surname ' - ' abbreviated title (repository)
Chapter in collection:
* Author surname ' - ' abbreviated title (abbreviated title of collection, publication year)
=== Theses ===
Author's surname - short title (thesis, year of completion)
For example:
* [[Robinson - Horse Supply (thesis, 2001)]]
== Disambiguation pages ==
The name of a disambiguation page should be the ambiguous term with nothing after it. This will be displayed in the page text by [[Template:Disambiguation page]].
Each disambiguation page should also have a redirect pointing to it with ' (disambiguation)' added after the page name.
[[Category:Help pages]]

revision.comment: /* Entering dates in transcripts and free text */ changed XML tag to wiki template
revision.text:
This page is about how to enter dates in forms, and how this site deals with the different calendars used in the past.
For quick reference, values for most date fields in forms should be entered like this:
* YYYY-MM-DD JL * YYYY-MM-DD GR
JL stands for the Julian calendar and GR for the Gregorian calendar (see below for more explanation of this).
For example, this is the date of the battle of Edgehill in each calendar:
* 1642-10-23 JL * 1642-11-02 GR
== The Julian and Gregorian calendars ==
The Julian calendar was used in most of Europe from ancient Rome until the 16th century. It got increasingly out of sync with the solar year because it had too many leap years. In 1582, the Catholic Church introduced the Gregorian calendar, which corrected the error. The new calendar was soon adopted by Catholic countries, and by some parts of the Netherlands, even though they were protestant and had already declared independence from Spain. Many other protestant and Eastern Orthodox countries only changed much later.
Great Britain and Ireland changed from the Julian to the Gregorian calendar in 1752, so documents from the British Civil Wars usually have Julian dates.
In the 17th century, the difference between the two calendars was 10 days. For example, 10 October Julian was 20 October Gregorian. The difference increased to 11 days in 1700 and is now 13 days. But note that the transition from Julian to Gregorian only changed the number of the day, not the day of the week, which is the same in both calendars. For example, the battle of Edgehill was fought on 23 October 1642 Julian, which was 2 November Gregorian, but it was a Sunday in both calendars.
Letters sent from a place that used one calendar to a place that used the other sometimes have double dates such as 10/20 October. This isn't always the case but you can tell which calendar was used if it also gives the day of the week. For example, Sunday 23 October 1642 must be Julian because 23 October 1642 Gregorian was a Thursday.
[http://people.albion.edu/imacinnes/calendar//Welcome.html Ian's English Calendar] can calculate the day of the week. You can also use the date tag on this site to automatically convert between calendars and find the day of the week (see below for more details).
For more information about calendars, see these Wikipedia pages:
* [[Wikipedia:Julian calendar|Julian calendar]] * [[Wikipedia:Gregorian calendar|Gregorian calendar]] * [[Wikipedia:Adoption of the Gregorian calendar|Adoption of the Gregorian calendar]] * [[Wikipedia:List of adoption dates of the Gregorian calendar per country|List of adoption dates of the Gregorian calendar per country]]
'''WARNING:''' Wikidata can store both Julian and Gregorian dates, but data has often been entered with the wrong calendar, so don't trust it.
The Julian calendar is sometimes known as Old Style and the Gregorian calendar is sometimes known as New Style, but these terms can also refer to the start of the new year, which is a different problem. See the next section below.
== The Old Style and New Style new years ==
New Style new year means starting the official year on 1 January (New Style can also refer to the Gregorian calendar, which is a different thing: see section above).
In Great Britain and Ireland, the Old Style new year was on the 25 March ''after'' 1 January (other Old Style new years have been used in other places and times, but these don't affect this project).
* Scotland changed to the New Style new year in 1600, but kept the Julian calendar until 1752 * England and Ireland changed to the New Style new year in 1752, at the same time as changing to the Gregorian calendar
Before these dates, documents dated from 1 January to 24 March can be ambiguous. Although the official new year started on 25 March, many people treated 1 January as the new year. For example, George Thomason, who collected the Thomason tracts, often wrote the Old Style year onto pamphlets that were printed with New Style years.
Modern printed editions of manuscripts often disambiguate dates by giving a double year. For example, 1 March 1644/5 means 1644 Old Style (year starting 25 March) and 1645 New Style (year starting 1 January).
Secondary sources often treat the year as starting on 1 January, and have a note at the start to say which calendar and new year style they are using.
This site follows the practice of most secondary sources: we treat the year as starting on 1 January, but otherwise use the calendar used in the original source. This means that if documents were created in England or Ireland between 1 January and 24 March in any year before 1752, you will need to convert the year to New Style but you don't need to convert between Julian and Gregorian dates.
'''WARNING:''' some online resources don't take the Old Style new year into account. Parish registers at [https://www.familysearch.org/ FamilySearch] can be misdated.
== Entering dates in form fields ==
Semantic properties that have the type [[Special:Types/Date|date]] are entered through form fields. If the form field doesn't yet have a value, it will display the text YYYY-MM-DD JL as a hint. This text will disappear when you start typing in the field.
Values for date fields in forms should be entered like this:
* YYYY-MM-DD JL * YYYY-MM-DD GR
That means a 4 digit year number, a 2 digit month number, and a 2 digit day number followed by JL for the Julian calendar or GR for the Gregorian calendar (see above for more explanation of this). There must be hyphens between the numbers, and a single space before the calendar code.
For example, this is the date of the battle of Edgehill in each calendar:
* 1642-10-23 JL * 1642-11-02 GR
Always specify which calendar you are using to avoid ambiguity (Semantic MediaWiki will make assumptions about the most appropriate calendar if you don't specify, but it's best practice to always be explicit).
You can enter a date in either calendar. It will automatically be displayed on the page with both Julian and Gregorian dates, and the day of the week.
It's usually best to use the same calendar as the documents that you are entering data about or using as evidence. If the document gives a double date with both the Julian and Gregorian day, you can use either but '''do not''' enter both at the same time as it won't work.
All dates entered in these form fields, whether Julian or Gregorian, should use 1 January as the start of the new year. You might need to modernize the year if it's from 1 January to 24 March. Some sources, especially modern printed editions of manuscript sources, might give a double year, such as 1644/5. In these cases, always use the second year given.
=== Uncertain dates ===
Date properties can store incomplete dates. You can leave out the day or month if they can't be known. For example:
* 1642 JL * 1642-10 JL
You should still specify the calendar in the source that the date comes from, as the discrepancy between the Julian and Gregorian calendars means that the months and years don't quite match.
You must always specify a year. Dates where the month and day are known but not the year can't be stored as semantic data. In these cases, just leave the date field blank but mention the incomplete date in free text somewhere else on the page.
=== Multiple dates ===
Most date fields can only take one date. The only exception is the date of a combat event. This can take multiple dates separated by a semi-colon if the event went on for more than one day.
=== Years only ===
The only exceptions to this format are:
* an author's year of death * year of publication of a book or article * year of completion of a thesis
These only take a year number with a maximum of 4 digits. This is stored as a [[Special:Types/Number|number]], not a date.
== Entering dates in transcripts and free text ==
You can use the template <nowiki>{{date}}</nowiki> to mark up a date in transcribed text, or format a date in free text. This template formats the date displayed on the page but does not store the date as a semantic property. It's similar to the [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-date.html TEI element <date>], but not exactly the same.
The date template should always have a parameter called 'when'. The value of this parameter should be a date in the same format as dates in form fields (see above). For example:
<nowiki>{{date|when=1642-10-23 JL}}</nowiki>
Just like form fields, the date can be entered as Julian or Gregorian, and you must use JL or GR to specify which one. This is different from the TEI date element, where @when must always be a Gregorian date in ISO format. TEI dates can also have many other attributes which we don't use here.
To abbreviate the names of days and months, you can add the parameter format=short.
=== Marking up dates in transcribed text ===
In transcripts, summaries or extracts of original sources, you can use the date template to mark up strings that refer to dates.
In this case, the first parameter should contain the original text. This will be displayed as it is. This parameter never has a name.
The value of the parameter 'when' should be the standardized form of the date. You should usually use the same calendar that the original source uses. If it specifies a double Julian and Gregorian date, such as 10/20 October 1642, you can use either calendar, but '''do not''' try to enter both at the same time as it won't work. The standardized date will automatically be displayed as a full date in both Julian and Gregorian calendars, with the day of the week.
For example, if you type this:
:<nowiki>{{date|when Edgehill fight was|when=1642-10-23 JL}}</nowiki>
it will be displayed as:
:{{date|when Edgehill fight was|when=1642-10-23 JL}}
If the day or month isn't known, the parameter 'when' can take incomplete dates in the same way as form fields. In this case, only a partial date will be displayed, in the same calendar that you specified, not a double date, because months and years without days can't easily be converted from one calendar to another.
If the year isn't known, or the date referred to can't be worked out at all, then it's not worth marking up the text as a date.
In 17th-century diaries and letters, it can be common for the day of the week and the number of the day to go out of sync. In these cases, the day of the week can sometimes be more reliable than the date. It's sometimes possible to work out the correct dates by following the sequence to where it went wrong.
When the date template has contents (usually the original text in a transcript) the formatted date will usually be displayed as a footnote. If you need to use a date template inside a footnote, you should add the parameter display=inline to stop the date tag from generating its own footnote, because you can't have a footnote inside a footnote. In this case, the formatted date will be displayed in square brackets after the original text. For example, if you type this:
:<nowiki>{{date|when Edgehill fight was|when=1642-10-23 JL|display=inline}}</nowiki>
it will be displayed as:
:{{date|when Edgehill fight was|when=1642-10-23 JL|display=inline}}
=== Formatting dates in free text ===
In free text other than transcripts of original sources, you can use the <nowiki>{{date}}</nowiki> template as an easy way to format a date with the correct day of the week and equivalent Julian and Gregorian dates.
In this case, the only parameter you always need to use is 'when', which should usually be a full date including year, month, day and calendar. If you don't specify a day, it will only display the partial date in the calendar that you specified, not a double date.
When used like this, the template never creates a footnote, so there is no need to use display=inline. The formatted date will be displayed inline where you type the template.
If you type:
:<nowiki>{{date|when=1642-10-23 JL}}</nowiki>
it will be displayed as:
:{{date|when=1642-10-23 JL}}
You can also use these optional parameter values to change the format of the date:
* format=short displays the date on one line as usual but abbreviates the names of days and months * format=column splits the date over three lines: ** day of the week spelt in full ** Julian date with abbreviated month ** Gregorian date with abbreviated month
== Displaying dates in query results ==
Query results display one date per column. By default, each date will be displayed in the same calendar that was specified when the date was entered. If you're writing your own query, you can force it to display dates in a certain calendar by appending:
* #JL for the Julian calendar * #GR for the Gregorian calendar
To display double dates, you will need to add a separate column for each calendar and specify the calendar using the codes above.
Note that in query results, Julian dates will be indicated with the suffix JL in superscript, but Gregorian dates won't have any suffix, unlike when they are displayed on the page they were entered on.
You can also change the formatting of dates in query results in other ways, and generate sort keys to sort query results into date order. For more details, see [https://www.semantic-mediawiki.org/wiki/Help:Type_Date Semantic MediaWiki help page for dates].
Note that if your query uses a date format that displays the day of the week, Julian dates will have the wrong day because of a bug in Semantic MediaWiki. This does not affect the way that dates are displayed on the pages where they were entered, where the day of the week shown will be correct for both the Julian and Gregorian calendars.
[[Category:Help pages]]

These entity types are used as values of [[Property:Is instance of]] in [[Form:Address]].
[[Category:Property values]]

* SEARCH * navigation ** mainpage|mainpage-description ** recentchanges-url|recentchanges ** randompage-url|randompage ** :Category:Categories|Category tree ** Help:Help|Help ** Help:Create a page|Create a page ** https://bytheswordlinked.hcommons.org| Project blog ** https://github.com/bytheswordlinkd/cc-by-sa-data/|Download data * Search ** Semantic searches|Semantic searches ** Events:Map of combat events|Map of combat events * TOOLBOX * LANGUAGES

These are the usual conventions for transcribed text used in text versions on pages for manuscript texts and sections, and printed copies. Transcripts published on this site do not claim to be scholarly editions. This site is primarily a finding aid and reference work. Transcripts are intended to make the contents of a document more accessible without distorting them too much, and to link records using inline wikilinks. The semantic structure and meaning of a document are treated as more important than its visual appearance. Some features are marked up by templates or symbols but there are some silent changes for ease of reading. If the transcription conventions used in a text version differ from these (for example, if the texts have been imported in bulk from another project), this should be stated in the template {{Intro}} (see the next section below for how to use this template). We are now using wiki templates instead of XML tags to mark up features of transcribed text. These templates are often similar to [http://www.tei-c.org/guidelines/p5/ TEI] tags but not exactly the same. Some templates use a MediaWiki extension to process and display custom XML tags, but there is no need to know about this when editing. == Introductory text == When adding a transcript of a source to that source's page, you should use the template {{Intro}} to add introductory information. The template has two unnamed parameters which can take any text. This text will automatically be formatted with a box around it to set it apart from the transcribed text. The parameters are used for: # Where the transcript came from and who made it. Any other information except for transcription conventions. # If this is not a full transcript, or if the transcription conventions are different from the standard ones given on this page (which may be true if the transcript was created by another project), please explain here. If this is a full transcript that uses our standard conventions, just leave this parameter out and the template will automatically link to this page. When you use the template {{Intro}} before the start of transcribed text, you should also use the template {{End of transcript}} after the end of the transcribed text. This helps to set the transcribed text apart from the rest of the page as it will have a different font and a horizontal line at the end. It also makes it easier for text miners to find transcribed text as it will be contained in this HTML code:
== Spelling, capitalization and punctuation == Original spelling, capitalization and punctuation are usually retained, except for: * ff at the start of a word is transcribed as F (some other projects transcribe it literally as ff but it should never be transcribed as Ff). This is because 17th-century secretary hand usually used a double lower case f to stand for capital F. * u/v is silently modernized. * i/j is silently modernized. In 17th-century manuscripts, u and v were often used interchangeably, and i and j were often used interchangeably (the same is true for the capital letters U/V and I/J). They should be changed to whatever makes most sense rather than being transcribed literally. For example, 'ivstice' should be transcribed as 'justice', 'Iohn' should be transcribed as 'John', 'uintner' should be transcribed as 'vintner'. Roman numerals are not converted to Arabic numerals. They are transcribed literally except that j is converted to i and u to v. The original capitalization is retained. For example, 'viij' is transcribed as 'viii', not 'viij' or '8'. == Indentation and alignment == All transcribed text should usually be aligned to the left. If the text in the original source is indented, centred, justified or right-aligned, this should be ignored. Indents can be created by formatting text as a bulleted list but this should only be done if the text is logically a list. == Abbreviations and expansion == Abbreviations are silently expanded without square brackets as far as possible. Superscript in abbreviations is transcribed as normal text. For example, if the original manuscript says: :Sr Wm Smith esq It should be transcribed as: :Sir William Smith esquire Ampersands should be transcribed literally as & == Insertions == The template {{add}} is used to mark up handwritten insertions that appear in the main text of a manuscript. This is similar to the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-add.html add]. The added text will be displayed as underlined text in the wiki page. This template has one unnamed parameter which contains the added text. For example, if you type this: :both {{add|horse and man}} are in good case You will get: :both {{add|horse and man}} are in good case For annotations outside the main text, such as marginal notes, use notes instead (see below). == Deletions == Deleted text is now always represented. It should be marked up with the template {{del}}. This is similar to the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-del.html del] but does not have any attributes. Text marked up with this tag is displayed as struck through text in the wiki page. This template has one unnamed parameter which should contain the deleted text. If you type this: :the {{del|the}} King You will get this: :the {{del|the}} King == Uncertain text == If text can be read but the reading is not certain, use the template {{?}}. This template has the same meaning as the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-unclear.html unclear]. It has one unnamed parameter. If you type: :we were all {{?|compleat}} in arms You will get this: :we were all {{?|compleat}} in arms == Illegible text == If text is completely missing because of damage to the document, or if it is present but cannot be read at all, use the template {{gap}}. This is equivalent to the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-gap.html gap] but does not have all of the same attributes. We only use the following parameters: * '''reason''' is human-readable text describing the reason for the gap in the text, such as "illegible" or "manuscript torn". A full stop will be added automatically, so don't include one in the text you type. * '''extent''' is human-readable text describing how much text is missing, such as "2 or 3 words" or "1 line". A full stop will be added automatically, so don't include one in the text you type. (We do not have any equivalent of @unit or @quantity.) Each gap template will usually be displayed in the wiki page as [...] followed by a footnote giving the extent of and reason for the gap. For example, if you type this: :listed one bay gelding with a {{gap|extent=half a line|reason=manuscript damaged}} You will get this: :listed one bay gelding with a {{gap|extent=half a line|reason=manuscript damaged}} If you need to mark up a gap inside a footnote, for example missing or illegible text in a later annotation, you should use the template {{gap inline}}. This has the same meaning and parameters as {{gap}} but displays the text in square brackets where the template is used instead of creating a footnote, because you can't have a footnote inside a footnote. For example, if you type this: :listed one bay gelding with a {{gap inline|extent=half a line|reason=manuscript damaged}} You will get this: :listed one bay gelding with a {{gap inline|extent=half a line|reason=manuscript damaged}} == Dates == You can use the template {{date}} to mark up dates in transcribed text. This has the same meaning as the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-date.html date] but @when has a different meaning from the TEI equivalent and it does not use any other attributes to record information about the date. For more information on how to use this tag and how to deal with different calendars, see [[Help:Dates]]. If you need to use this tag inside a footnote, you should add the parameter display=inline to stop the date tag from generating its own footnote, because you can't have a footnote inside a footnote. == Named entities == We have several templates to mark up text that refers to named entities such as people and places. These all have the same meaning as the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-rs.html rs], '''not''' the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-name.html name], which has a more specific meaning. TEI tags can only be used for proper nouns, but our templates and the TEI tag can also be used for other strings that refer to an entity without being its actual name, for example: * her husband * the Queen * the Lord General * your horseman To mark up names in the main text of a transcribed document, you can use one of these templates: * {{name key}} where a string refers to exactly one entity that can be positively identified. This creates an inline link in the text, and creates a semantic link using [[Property:Mentions]]. * {{name keys}} where a string refers to more than one entity at the same time, and they can be positively identified. This creates a footnote containing links to all entities identified, and creates semantic links using [[Property:Mentions]]. * {{name couldbe}} where a string refers to one or more entities which have not been positively identified but there are one or more possibilities. This creates a footnote containing links to all possibilities, and creates semantic links using [[Property:Possibly mentions]]. * {{name unid}} where a string refers to one or more entities that have not been identified at all and no possibilities can be suggested. This creates a footnote saying 'Unidentified' and adds the original text to [[Property:Mentions unidentified name]]. In all of these templates, the parameters are unnamed. * The first parameter should contain the actual name string used in the transcribed text. This is the only parameter in {{name unid}}. * The second parameter (not used by {{name unid}}) contains the page names of entities that the string definitely or possibly refers to. ** in {{name key}} this must be exactly one page name ** in {{name keys}} and {{name couldbe}} this can be one or more page names, separated by ; as in form fields. Examples of correct use of these tag: * Identified as referring to one entity: {{name key|the Lord General|Devereux, Robert (3rd Earl of Essex)}} * Identified as referring to two entities at the same time: {{name keys|the two Creetings|Creeting St Peter, Suffolk, England;Creeting St Mary, Suffolk, England}} * Could be one or the other: {{name couldbe|Richard Blissett|Blissett, Richard senior (harness maker);Blissett, Richard junior (harness maker)}} * Completely unidentified: {{name unid|Mr Smith}} === Inline markup of named entities inside footnotes === If you need to mark up names inside a footnote, the following templates must not be used because they create footnotes, which won't work if they are already inside a footnote: * {{name keys}} * {{name couldbe}} * {{name unid}} Instead, use one of the following equivalents, which will display the links or text inline without creating a footnote: * {{name keys inline}} * {{name couldbe inline}} * {{name unid inline}} For example: * {{note ms|{{name couldbe inline|Richard Blissett|Blissett, Richard senior (harness maker);Blissett, Richard junior (harness maker)}} his booke}} == Notes == You can create footnotes with the templates listed below. We don't recommend using tags because there are rare circumstances where XML tags can cause problems, and for the sake of consistency because our current practice is to use wiki templates for all markup. If you need to use {{date}} or {{gap}} templates inside a footnote, they must have the parameter display=inline. Otherwise these templates will generate their own footnotes, which won't work inside a footnote. Similarly, templates for marking up names must use the inline versions ([[#Inline markup of named entities inside footnotes|see above]]). These templates each have one unnamed parameter. They all work in the same way, but each template is used for a different purpose: * {{note}} is used to create footnotes for citations in free text other than transcripts of sources. This has the same effect as a tag at Wikipedia. We do not use citation templates like Wikipedia because our linked data approach removes the need to repeat all of the citation information every time a source is cited. Citations should usually contain an internal link to a source that is represented by a page on this wiki and/or an external link to a source that has been published on another website. You can combine both to link to an edition represented by a page on this wiki and the relevant page at the Internet Archive. * these templates are used to mark up transcripts of sources. They have a similar meaning to the TEI element [https://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-note.html ], 'marked in some way as being out of the main textual stream': ** {{note ed}} for new editorial notes added in this wiki. These will automatically be prefixed with 'Editorial note'. ** {{note print}} for original footnotes, endnotes or marginal notes printed in an early printed text. These will automatically be prefixed with 'Printed note'. ** {{note ms}} for handwritten notes found in a text. These will automatically be prefixed with 'Manuscript note'. Manuscript notes can be: *** handwritten marginalia in a printed text *** additions to manuscript text 'marked in some way as being out of the main textual stream'.{{note|[http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/CO.html#CONONO TEI P5 guidelines].}} But for contemporary additions or alterations that are part of the main text, use the template {{add}} instead. === Examples === ==== Citation in free text ==== If you type: :Strength in July 1644: 11 officers, 74 troopers{{note|[[Symonds - Diary (Long edition, 1859)]], [https://archive.org/stream/diarymarchesroy00librgoog#page/n99/mode/2up page 73].}} You will get: :Strength in July 1644: 11 officers, 74 troopers{{note|[[Symonds - Diary (Long edition, 1859)]], [https://archive.org/stream/diarymarchesroy00librgoog#page/n99/mode/2up page 73].}} ==== Original footnote in printed text ==== If you type: :These forms (in Walhausens opinion) are of {{note print|So the said author conceiveth; but it is very doubtfull.}} speciall advantage You will get: :These forms (in Walhausens opinion) are of {{note print|So the said author conceiveth; but it is very doubtfull.}} speciall advantage ==== Contemporary annotation in manuscript ==== If you type: :Demi-culverins 4, horses to draw them 60{{note ms|12 horses enough}} You will get: :Demi-culverins 4, horses to draw them 60{{note ms|12 horses enough}} ==== Marginalia in printed text ==== If you type: :is perswaded into Cornwal to credit Roberts for getting his Rents{{note ms|This is a base lie}} You will get: :is perswaded into Cornwal to credit Roberts for getting his Rents{{note ms|This is a base lie}} ==== New editorial note ==== If you type: :In the end of this month of May died Mr. John Pym{{note ed|This is an error. Pym died in December 1643.}} You will get: :In the end of this month of May died Mr. John Pym{{note ed|This is an error. Pym died in December 1643.}} == Headings == Wiki markup can be used to represent logical headings in the transcribed text. For example, an account book might have section headings for dates or administrative areas. See [[Wikipedia:Help:Section]] for more information about heading markup. Each text transcript version is under a level 2 heading. This means that headings marked up within the transcript should start at level 3. For example: === 12o Oct[ober] 1643 === == Lists == You can use wiki markup to create bulleted lists for things that are logically lists, even if they don't have bullets in the original text. To create a one-level list, just put * at the start of each line and a single line break at the end of the line. For example, if you type this: 
* Colonel Cromwells troop
* Major Whaleys troop
* Captain Swallows troop
It will be displayed as: * Colonel Cromwells troop * Major Whaleys troop * Captain Swallows troop For more complex lists, you can add extra levels by adding an extra * at the start of the line. For example, if you type this: 
* Colonel Cromwells regiment
** Colonel Cromwells own troop
** Major Whaleys troop
** Captain Swallows troop
* Colonel Fleetwoods regiment
It will be displayed as: * Colonel Cromwells regiment ** Colonel Cromwells own troop ** Major Whaleys troop ** Captain Swallows troop * Colonel Fleetwoods regiment You can create numbered lists by using # instead of * but there are likely to be fewer cases where these are useful. == Tables == Wiki tables can be used to represent layouts that are logically tables, even if the manuscript does not draw lines around the rows and columns. For example, many account books are laid out like tables. See [[Wikipedia:Help:Table]] for the basics of how to mark up tables. == Bold, italic and black letter text == Italic text in transcripts of printed sources should represented by wiki markup for italics, which is two single quote marks before and two after the italic text. For example, if you type this: I shall be made a ''Bishop'', and grow fat It will be displayed as: I shall be made a ''Bishop'', and grow fat Bold text is used to represent black letter type in transcripts of early printed sources. The wiki markup for bold text is three single quote marks before and three after. For example, if you type this: '''It chanced that I carried a young Maid''' It will be displayed as: '''It chanced that I carried a young Maid''' == Page breaks == You can use the one of the following templates to represent a break in the transcribed text. These are similar to the TEI element [http://www-old.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-pb.html pb]. * {{p}} for a page. This is the usual numbering system in modern printed texts, and is also found in some manuscripts. Some early printed texts use signatures instead. A page number usually refers to one side of the paper. The front and back will have different numbers. * {{f}} for a folio. This is the usual numbering system in manuscripts, but some may have page numbers. A folio number usually refers to one sheet of paper in a manuscript. The number should be qualified with r for recto (the front of the sheet, which is on the right when viewed in a bound volume) or v for verso (the back of the sheet, which appears on the left when viewed in a bound volume). * {{col}} for a column. Some printed books have more than one column on each page, and each column has a unique number. * {{sig}} for signature mark, which is sometimes found in early printed texts instead of page numbers. These are often a capital letter followed by a number, followed by r for recto or v for verso. These templates all use the same parameters. Parameter names can be omitted if the values are entered in this order: # '''n''' is the number of the page, folio, column, or signature. It can be omitted if there is no numbering system. For folios and signatures, the number should be followed by r for recto or v for verso. If present, the template will use this parameter to create a unique ID for the break that you can link to directly by appending # and the ID to the end of a page name in a wiki link. The ID will be structured like p245 or f245r etc. # '''facs''' contains a URL to link to an image of the page if one is available somewhere else on the web. For example, many printed sources have page scans freely available at the Internet Archive. This is the same as @facs in the TEI pb element. These templates should not contain any transcribed text. Examples: A folio in a manuscript. If you type this: {{f|42v}} It will be displayed as: {{f|42v}} A page in the published diary of Richard Symonds, with a link to the page image at the Internet Archive. If you type this: {{p|73|https://archive.org/details/diarymarchesroy00librgoog/page/n99}} It will be displayed as: {{p|73|https://archive.org/details/diarymarchesroy00librgoog/page/n99}} A page break in a text with no numbering system: If you type this: {{p}} It will be displayed as: {{p}} == Line breaks == Line breaks in the original text are not usually represented here. Optionally you can represent them in the editing form for ease of proofreading by typing a single line break but this will be ignored when the page is displayed. MediaWiki treats a single line break as a space when displaying the page. [[Category:Help pages]]

This is a subset of [[modern edition]] where the book is an edited collection that contains several [[article]]s.
